doc.title: Ælfheah of Canterbury
doc.text:
953 – 19 April 1012
) was an
, later
. He became an
before being elected abbot of
. His reputation for piety and sanctity led to his promotion to the

, and eventually
, to his becoming archbishop. Ælfheah furthered the cult of
and also encouraged learning. He was captured by
raiders in 1011 and killed by them the following year after refusing to allow himself to be ransomed. Ælfheah was
as a

, a later Archbishop of Canterbury
, prayed to him just before his own murder in

doc.text: Purportedly born in

on the outskirts of Bath
,
Ælfheah became a monk early in life. His birth took place around 953.
He first entered the monastery of
, but then moved to
, where he became an anchorite. He was noted for his piety and austerity and rose to become
of Bath Abbey.
The 12th century chronicler
recorded that Ælfheah was a monk and prior at

but this is not accepted by all historians. Indications are that Ælfheah became abbot at Bath by 982
, perhaps as early as around 977. He perhaps shared authority with his predecessor Æscwig after 968. Probably due to the influence of Dunstan
, the Archbishop of Canterbury
(959–988
), Ælfheah was elected Bishop of Winchester in 984
,
and was consecrated on 19 October that year. While bishop he was largely responsible for the construction of a large
in the

, audible from over a mile
(1600 m
) away and said to require more than 24 men to operate. He also built and enlarged the city's churches
,
and promoted the cult of

and his own predecessor
,
. One act promoting Æthelwold's cult was the

of Æthelwold's body to a new tomb in the cathedral at Winchester
, which Ælfheah presided over on 10 September 996.

Following a Viking raid in 994
, a peace treaty was agreed with one of the raiders
,
. Besides receiving
, Olaf converted to Christianity
and undertook never to raid or fight the English again.

Ælfheah may have played a part in the treaty negotiations
, and it is certain that he confirmed Olaf in his new faith.
In 1006 Ælfheah succeeded

as Archbishop of Canterbury
,
taking Swithun's head with him as a
for the new location. He went to Rome in 1007 to receive his

of his status as an archbishop
—from Pope
, but was robbed during his journey.

While at Canterbury he promoted the cult of Dunstan
, ordering the writing of the second
, which
composed between 1006 and 1011.

He also introduced new practices into the liturgy
, and was instrumental in the
's recognition of
as a saint in about 1012.
to
to take charge of its monastic school.
He was present at the council of May 1008 at which
, preached his

entity.text: The Sermon of the Wolf to the English

doc.text: ), castigating the English for their moral failings and blaming the latter for the tribulations afflicting the country.
In 1011 the

again raided England
, and from 8–29 September they laid siege to Canterbury. Aided by the treachery of Ælfmaer
, whose life Ælfheah had once saved
, the raiders succeeded in sacking the city.
Ælfheah was taken prisoner and held captive for seven months.

(abbess of St Mildrith's
), and the king's

, Ælfweard were captured also
, but the abbot of
, managed to escape. Canterbury Cathedral was plundered and burned by the Danes following Ælfheah's capture.

entity.text: Heads of Religious Houses, England and Wales
A Brief History of the Anglo-Saxons

citation.attr: How exactly Ælfheah had saved Ælfmaer's life is not recorded in any source.

doc.text:
Ælfheah refused to allow a ransom to be paid for his freedom
, and as a result was killed on 19 April 1012 at
(then in

, now part of London
), reputedly on the site of
. The account of Ælfheah's death appears in the E version of the
Ælfheah was the first Archbishop of Canterbury to die a violent death.
A contemporary report tells that

attempted to save Ælfheah from the mob about to kill him by offering everything he owned except for his ship
, in exchange for Ælfheah's life
; Thorkell's presence is not mentioned in the
, however.

Some sources record that the final blow
, with the back of an axe
, was delivered as an
by a Christian convert known as
Ælfheah was buried in
. In 1023 his body was moved by King
to
, with great ceremony.

Thorkell the Tall was appalled at the brutality of his fellow raiders
, and switched sides to the English king
following Ælfheah's death.

attr.text:
... the raiding-army became much stirred up against the bishop
, because he did not want to offer them any money
, and forbade that anything might be granted in return for him. Also they were very drunk
, because there was wine brought from the south. Then they seized the bishop
, led him to their

on the Saturday in the octave of Easter
, and then pelted him there with bones and the heads of cattle
; and one of them struck him on the head with the butt of an axe
, so that with the blow he sank down and his holy blood fell on the earth
, and sent forth his holy soul to God's kingdom.

Except perhaps for a finger
, which a later tradition held was given by Cnut to

doc.text:
canonised Ælfheah in 1078
, with a
of 19 April.
, the first

archbishop
, was dubious about some of the saints venerated at Canterbury. He was persuaded of Ælfheah's sanctity
,
but Ælfheah and
were the only pre-conquest Anglo-Saxon archbishops kept on Canterbury's calendar of saints.

Ælfheah's shrine
, which had become neglected
, was rebuilt and expanded in the early 12th century under
, who was instrumental in retaining Ælfheah's name in the church calendar.

After the 1174 fire in Canterbury Cathedral
, Ælfheah's remains together with those of Dunstan were placed around the high altar
, at which Thomas Becket is said to have commended his life into Ælfheah's care shortly before his martyrdom during the

. The new shrine was sealed in lead
,

and was north of the high altar
, sharing the honour with Dunstan's shrine
, which was located south of the high altar.
A
in prose and verse was written by a Canterbury monk named

, at Lanfranc's request. The prose version has survived
, but the
is very much a

: many of the stories it contains have obvious Biblical parallels
, making them suspect as a historical record. In the late medieval period
, Ælfheah's feast day was celebrated in Scandinavia
, perhaps because of the saint's connection with Cnut.

Few church dedications to him are known
, with most of them occurring in Kent and one each in London and Winchester
; as well as

in Greenwich
, a

(1931–1968
) was named after him.
In the town of Solihull in the West Midlands
is dedicated to Ælfheah dating back to approximately 1277.

In 1929 a new church in Bath was dedicated to Ælfheah
, under the name Alphege
, designed by
in homage to the ancient Roman church of
